metadata.case_name: Appellants (Plaintiffs, successors of Hiranand Jha) v. Respondents (Defendants first party, Parameshwar Dayal and others)

facts.text: Village Darha belonged to a family of Pathaks as their ancestral lakhraj. Over a hundred years ago the Pathaks granted the entire village in mokarrari to the ancestors of the family of Singhas (defendants first and second parties) at an annual jama of Rs. 24.

The mokarrari interest eventually devolved on three branches of the Singha family: Parameshwar Dayal and others (defendants first party) - six annas; Bisheswar Dayal Singh (defendants second party) - eight annas; Madho Saran Singh - two annas.

Subsequently, the two anna share of Madho Saran Singh was purchased by Hiranand Jha, father of the plaintiffs, jointly with Durganand Jha and Dharam Dayal (Dharam Dayal was a mere benamidar for Hiranand Jha).
On 5th June 1916, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh purchased six anna share in the lakhraj interest from Deolal Pathak and others.

On 9th February 1917, Bisheshwar Dayal Singh purchased another two anna share in lakhraj interest from Mandil Pathak. By virtue of these, he owned eight anna lakhraj interest (already held eight anna mokarrari by inheritance).

In 1917 or 1918, Hiranand Jha and Durganand Jha purchased in execution of a rent decree the raiyati interest in the whole village and came into possession. Thus became mokarraridars of two anna share and raiyats of sixteen annas.

In 1918, Title Suit No. 59 of 1918 instituted for partition of lands including Darha. Jhas impleaded as co-sharers. Decreed in 1921: Jhas allotted two annas share in Darha; defendants first party - fourteen annas excluding khatians 1,3,6; Bisheshwar - three khatians, exchanged for property in Holeya.
Final partition in 1921: defendants first party hold fourteen anna mokarrari in Darha; Bisheshwar limited to three khatians; Jhas separate two anna mokarrari allotment.

About 1926, lakhraj holders (Pathaks and Bisheshwar) defaulted on cess. Proceedings 17th August 1926, sold 18th October 1927 to Bijainandan Sahay (lakhraj interest). Confirmed 19th December 1927, certificate 20th March 1928, possession 15th July 1928 to Kamta Prasad (purchased from Bijainandan 20th April 1928).
On 1st May 1933, Kamta Prasad transferred interest to plaintiffs, who became proprietors of sixteen anna share, mokarraridars two anna, raiyats sixteen annas.
21st September 1934, defendants first party sued plaintiffs for arrears of raiyati rent: 1338-39 F. six annas; 1340-41 F. fourteen annas, claiming fourteen anna mokarrari under partition.

Plaintiffs contested rent suit alleging Bisheshwar's mokarrari merged in lakhraj purchased 1916-17, sold under certificate (eight annas both interests passed to plaintiffs); defendants first party only six annas rent. Plea disallowed, decree for full rent upheld on appeals, title left open.

1938, another rent suit by defendants first party for fourteen annas post-1341 F. Plaintiffs filed present suit No.9/1939 for declarations: eight anna mokarrari of Bisheshwar merged in lakhraj, lost via sale; partition 1921 illegal or only six annas to defendants first party; private partition among mokarraridars; partition among lakhraj owners.
Trial court (Subordinate Judge Palamau): both partitions proved, merger, defendants first party six annas mokarrari only; decreed plaintiffs' suit.
High Court Patna (14 Feb 1946): neither partition proved; no merger of eight annas mokarrari in sixteen annas lakhraj; dismissed suit.

legal_issues.text: Whether the mokarrari interest of eight annas of Bisheshwar Dayal Singh merged in his lakhraj interest of eight annas (purchased from Pathaks), such that it passed entirely to the purchasers under the certificate sale of lakhraj interest, leaving defendants first party with only six annas mokarrari.
Whether the alleged private partitions among mokarraridars and among lakhraj owners were proved and effected merger.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erroneously held two partitions (paras 5 and 8 of plaint) not proved; evidence establishes partitions; Bisheshwar became separate owner of eight anna lakhraj, his mokarrari merged therein; whole interest passed under certificate sale; defendants first party only six anna mokarrari rent.

respondent_arguments.text: Neither partition proved; mokarrari of eight annas could not merge in lakhraj of sixteen annas held jointly by Bisheshwar with Pathaks.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiffs' case rests on merger of Bisheshwar's eight anna mokarrari in his lakhraj; no scope for merger doctrine: lessor purchasing lessee's interest extinguishes lease, but not if one lessee purchases part of lessor's interest; no coincidence of leasehold and reversion as Bisheshwar owned only moiety of lakhraj, not entire.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere purchase by Bisheshwar of portions of lakhraj could not extinguish lease or break integrity as he was one of several joint mokarraridars.

court_reasoning.text: Inter se partition among mokarraridars does not affect liability to lessor (several tenants constitute single tenant); privity of estate remains; no severance of tenancy alleged.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partitions for convenience do not affect integrity of tenancy.

court_reasoning.text: Inter se partition among lakhraj owners does not affect lease integrity without fresh contract; lakhraj remains single holding; default by all led to sale of whole.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No conditions for merger made out; lease live for six annas of defendants first party, cannot be extinct for eight annas without fresh contract.

holdings.text: Doctrine of merger not applicable; Bisheshwar's mokarrari did not merge in lakhraj; no coalescence of lessor and lessee interests in whole estate.
Alleged partitions do not affect lease integrity or cause merger.

precedents_cited.relevance: Several tenants hold as tenants in common but pay one rent; privity of estate in whole leasehold.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed on the short point of no merger of Bisheshwar's mokarrari interest in his partial lakhraj interest; partitions do not affect lease integrity; plaintiffs' suit dismissed as per High Court.

key_quotes.text: If the lessor purchases the lessees interest, the lease no doubt is extinguished as the same man cannot at the same time be both a landlord and a tenant, but there is no extinction of the lease if one of the several lessees purchases only a part of the lessors interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning rejecting merger doctrine application.

key_quotes.text: In the words of Lord Halsbury in White v. Tyndall, the parties to whom a demise is made hold as tenants in common but what they covenant to pay is one rent, not two rents and not each to pay half a rent but one rent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains joint tenant liability preserving lease integrity.
